data.text:
Finding a Home in Writing

Poet and novelist Sandra Cisneros (b. 1954) is best known for her novel The House on Mango Street (1983). Born in Chicago, Illinois, Cisneros was the only girl in a family of seven children. When she was a child, her father moved the family several times between Chicago and Mexico City, the capital of Mexico. With these moves back and forth between the two countries, Cisneros felt detached from both cultures, forcing her to create her own path to understand herself better.

In school, Cisneros was encouraged to write poems and quickly became known for her writing. However, her interest in writing did not fully take hold until college, when she took a creative writing course. She graduated with a BA from Loyola University in Chicago in 1976 and earned an MFA from the Writersâ Workshop at the University of Iowa in 1978. While there, she had an epiphany: âI was in this class, we were talking about memory and the imagination,â¦ and I realized: âMy god, Iâmâ¦ different from everybody in this classroomââ (RodrÃ­guez Aranda 65). This important reflection encouraged Cisneros to write about what others could not: her own experience. The unique part poetry, part prose writing style that she crafted to relay her experiences eventually found its place among traditional literary genres, giving voice to the once voiceless.

In her memoir, A House of My Own: Stories from My Life (2015), Cisneros reflects on her journey as a writer through subjects such as autonomy, home, culture, and environment. She does so by introducing her memories, which develop into a kind of dialogue between the young writer she once was and the successful writer she is today. In the title essay, âA House of My Ownââoriginally the introduction to the 25th anniversary edition of The House on Mango StreetâCisneros writes, âThe young woman in this photograph is me.â¦ She thinks stories are about beauty.â By describing herself in the third person from the vantage point of herself as a successful writer, Cisneros creates space for reflectionâthe act of thinking about the arc of her life. She wonders how this young woman with so many fears had the courage to chart her own path in life. Upon reflection, previously unexamined gifts from her parents provide some answers. In A House of My Own, Cisneros says that she became a writer because of her mother, âwho was unhappy being a motherâ and was âbanging on the bars of her cell all her life,â and because of her father, who wanted Cisneros to marry and have babies and so didnât mind if she âmajored in something silly like Englishâ: âIn a sense, everything I have ever written has been for him, to win his approval.â Cisnerosâs reflection suggests that in some ways, her life has been about rebirthing herself into a form that her mother would be proud of and a form her father would come to understandâa form beyond the circumstances of her original birth.

This reflective dialogue across time mirrors the way in which Cisneros sees herself: as someone who writes from multiple perspectives. Being an American and a Mexican, she writes in two languages and uses elements of both cultures to create characters that she picks up from memory, chance meetings, visits to various places, and dreams. She cobbles these parts together to form a title or maybe just a first line, giving her mind time to percolate, waiting for the rest of the story to emerge. This is the work of reflectionâgiving oneself time to think, to make connections, to feel, and to put words to ideas.
